results.name: NCDOT_Traffic_Signals_Public_View
results.title: NCDOT Traffic Signals Public View
results.description:
This service provides a point dataset representing state-owned traffic signals. This Feature Layer service does not include signals currently owned by local governments or municipalities.

The points in this service are symbolized to indicate a traffic signal or flasher.

The traffic signals contain these data attribute fields:
  • Signal (ID)
  • Location
  • City
  • County
  • Flasher (Flasher or Signal)
  • Latitude
  • Longitude
  • Signal System
  • System Description
  • Local/Master
  • Signal Plans (link to online signal plans)
  • Google Map (link to signal location in Google Maps)
This service is included in the public┬áTraffic Signals Map.

Point of Contact┬á
North Carolina Department of Transportation, Transportation Systems Management & Operations
ITS and Signals Management Section
Contact information:
TMSSU@ncdot.gov
750 N. Greenfield Parkway
Garner, NC 27529

Hours of service: 9:00am - 5:00pm Monday – Friday

Contact instructions: Please send an email with any issues, questions, or comments regarding the Traffic Signals data. If it is an immediate need, please indicate as such in the subject line in an email.
results.snippet:
Please sign in to ArcGIS Online for the Export Data button to appear.

Included within is a projection of NCDOT owned signals and flashers throughout the state of North Carolina. Not included within are signals that are currently owned by local municipalities or governments.
results.accessInformation: NCDOT Transportation Systems Management and Operations
results.licenseInfo: The North Carolina Department of Transportation shall not be held liable for any errors in this data. This includes errors of omission, commission, errors concerning the content of the data, and relative and positional accuracy of the data. This data cannot be construed to be a legal document. Primary sources from which this data was compiled must be consulted for verification of information contained in this data.

results.title: Maryland Traffic Signals
results.description:
Esri ArcGIS Online (AGOL) Feature Layer which provides access to the Maryland Traffic Signals data product.

Maryland Traffic Signals data consists of point geometric features which represent the geographic locations of devices / signals used to control & direct traffic along roadways throughout the State of Maryland.

Maryland Traffic Signals data is owned & maintained by the MDOT SHA Office of Traffic & Safety (OOTS). This data product is updated through an automated weekly routine.┬á┬á

For more information, contact MDOT SHA OIT Enterprise Information Services:
Email:┬áGIS@mdot.maryland.gov
results.snippet: Maryland Traffic Signals data consists of point geometric features which represent the geographic locations of devices / signals used to control & direct traffic along roadways throughout the State of Maryland.  This data product is owned & maintained by the MDOT SHA Office of Traffic & Safety (OOTS).

results.name: TRANSPORTATION_signals2
results.title: Traffic Signals and Pedestrian Signals
results.description: This layer contains information about traffic and pedestrian signals┬á in the city of Austin, Texas. The data is maintained by the Austin Transportation Department Arterial Management Division and is updated daily. If you have questions about this data you can contact transportation.data@austintexas.gov.
results.snippet: Point layer identifying the location and basic attributes of traffic and pedestrian signals in Austin, TX.
results.licenseInfo:
This product is for informational purposes and may not have been prepared for or be suitable for legal, engineering, or surveying purposes. It does not represent and on-the-ground survey and represents only the approximate relative location of property boundaries.

This product has been produced by Austin Transportation Department for the sole purpose of geographic reference. No warranty is made by the City of Austin regarding specific accuracy or completeness.

results.title: NCDOT Traffic Signals
results.description:
This web map service provides a point dataset representing state-owned traffic signals. This Feature Layer service does not include signals currently owned by local governments or municipalities.

The traffic signals points in this service are symbolized to indicate a traffic signal or flasher. Signal ID labels appear when zoomed in closer to the data in the map.

The traffic signals contain these data attribute fields, viewable in the popup window when clicking a point in the map:
  • Signal (ID)
  • Location
  • City
  • County
  • Flasher (Flasher or Signal)
  • Latitude
  • Longitude
  • Signal System
  • System Description
  • Local/Master
  • Signal Plans (link to online signal plans)
  • Google Map (link to signal location in Google Maps)
Information about the additional data included in this map can be accessed by selecting an item below.
  • Safety Projects – Section and Intersection Projects
  • SPOT Mobility Projects – Section and Intersection Projects
  • NCDOT State Maintained Roads
  • NCDOT Statutory Speed Limits
  • NCDOT Current 2024-2033 STIP
  • NCDOT Bridges
  • NCDOT Division Boundaries
  • NCDOT County Boundaries
  • NCDOT City Boundaries
Metadata┬á

Data metadata is available for these layers contained in the NCDOT Traffic Signal Maintenance Statewide Admin Map through the following links:

NCDOT State┬á Maintained Roads

NCDOT Statutory Speed Limits

NCDOT Current 2024-2033 STIP Lines

NCDOT Current 2024-2033 STIP Points

NCDOT Bridges

NCDOT Division Boundaries

NCDOT County Boundaries

NCDOT City Boundaries

Point of Contact┬á
North Carolina Department of Transportation, Transportation Systems Management & Operations
ITS and Signals Management Section
Contact information:
TMSSU@ncdot.gov
750 N. Greenfield Parkway
Garner, NC 27529

Hours of service: 9:00am - 5:00pm Monday – Friday

Contact instructions: Please send an email with any issues, questions, or comments regarding the Traffic Signals Map. If it is an immediate need, please indicate as such in the subject line in an email.
results.snippet: Included within is a projection of NCDOT owned signals and flashers throughout the state of North Carolina. Not included within are signals that are currently owned by local municipalities or governments.

Primary sources from which this data was compiled must be consulted for verification of information contained in this data.┬á

results.name: ACTGOV_Traffic_Signal_Site_Assets
results.title: ACTGOV Traffic Signal Site Assets
results.description:
This point dataset shows the locations of Traffic Signal Sites in the Australian Capital Territory.

These assets are either owned or managed by City Services, City and Environment Directorate (CED). Assets managed and / or owned privately, by other ACT Government Directorates or by the Federal Government may not be included.

Attributes include location description, suburb, ownership, maintained by, asset sub type (Cross, Part Time, Pedestrian, Tee) and commissioning, connection, modification and replacement dates.

These assets are captured and maintained in the asset database through the works as executed (WAE) handover process or field audits.

For additional information, please see the relevant municipal infrastructure standard (https://www.cityservices.act.gov.au/plan-and-build/standards-codes-and-guidelines/municipal-infrastructure-design-standards-mis).
results.snippet: Locations of Traffic Signal Sites owned or managed by CED in the Australian Capital Territory.
results.licenseInfo:
Creative Commons By Attribution 4.0 (Australian Capital Territory)

Please read Data Terms and Conditions statement before data use (https://www.actmapi.act.gov.au/terms-and-conditions).

results.name: TRANSPORTATION_signal_requests
results.title: Traffic Signal and Pedestrian Signal Requests
results.description: This layer contains information about traffic and pedestrian signal requests in the city of Austin, Texas. In addition to the specific location of the request, the layer includes data related to the status of the signal request. The data is updated daily by the Arterial Management Division of the Austin Transportation Department.
results.snippet: Point layer identifying the location and basic attributes of traffic and pedestrian signal requests in Austin, TX.
results.licenseInfo:
This product is for informational purposes and may not have been prepared for or be suitable for legal, engineering, or surveying purposes. It does not represent and on-the-ground survey and represents only the approximate relative location of property boundaries.

This product has been produced by Austin Transportation Department for the sole purpose of geographic reference. No warranty is made by the City of Austin regarding specific accuracy or completeness.

results.name: Curb_Ramps_and_Signals_2023_and_Earlier
results.title: Pedestrian Curb Ramp and Signal Button Inspections - 2018 to 2023
results.description:
A hosted feature service that includes parent intersection points (categorized by their construction status), pedestrian curb ramps/crossing locations (those with detectable surfaces AND without), pedestrian signal buttons, and now-deprecated pedestrian street crossing records. The latter are included for historical reference or substitution in areas where crosswalks have not been re-collected or converted to sidewalk line records.

Data is collected in the field each year May through October and is updated in real time as new records are added.┬á Information on specific project areas is generally collected the spring or summer of the year after the project's completion.┬á┬áPlease note: this version of the curb ramp and signal button data will soon be transformed and consolidated with┬áthe 2024-onward version.┬á When that consolidation is complete (sometime in the first half of 2025), this frozen data will be deprecated and removed from ArcGIS Online.

This data is not intended to┬ásupersede┬ácompliance assessments completed by construction inspectors.┬á Noncompliance (or inability to calculate compliance) for individual features in this data may be present due to errors in field data collection, missing attribution, or simply the age of the data.┬á Quality control efforts and refinements to data collection processes are ongoing.

Pedestrian curb ramps are categorized by the corner configuration to which they belong:
  • Depressed Corner
  • Diagonal
  • Fan
  • One-Way Directional
  • Parallel
  • Perpendicular
  • Rural Pad
  • None (no curb cut/curb only)
  • Other
Pedestrian crossing push-button locations (sometimes referred to as APS, or Accessible Pedestrian Signals) are categorized by their general location and include attributes collected concerning the buttons themselves as well as other components of the crossing signal system.┬á Attributes are collected with an eye towards ADA compliance, but at present the compliance metrics are undergoing revision so signal points are not symbolized by ADA compliance the way pedestrian curb ramps are.

For more information on MnDOT's ADA policies and procedures, please refer to this site:┬áMnDOT Accessibility (state.mn.us)

If you have specific questions regarding ADA/pedestrian infrastructure planning & policies, please contact Kristie Billiar (kristie.billiar@state.mn.us).
If you have specific questions regarding pedestrian infrastructure data and analysis, please contact Galen Sjostrom (galen.sjostrom@state.mn.us).
results.snippet: A frozen view of curb ramp and pedestrian signal inventories within MnDOT's approximate right-of-way collected between 2018 and 2023.  Intersection points also included for data aggregation.
results.accessInformation: Minnesota Department of Transportation, Asset Management Group and Statewide ADA Compliance Unit
results.licenseInfo:
USE OF THIS DOCUMENT IS SUBJECT TO MNDOT'S DISCLAIMERS, LEGAL NOTICES AND POLICIES FOUND at┬áhttps://www.dot.state.mn.us/information/disclaimer.html

results.name: Curb_Ramp_and_Ped_Signal_Collection_2024_Onward_
results.title: Pedestrian Location Inventory with Curb Ramp & Signal Button Inspections
results.description:
This is a revised version of what is traditionally known as the MnDOT Pedestrian Curb Ramp Inventory.  It now matches the forthcoming Transportation Asset Management System (TAMS) schema, which will be the system of record for both pedestrian ramps and signals, as well as sidewalk data, starting sometime late 2025 or early  2026.

This version simplifies the previous data; instead of parent intersection points with individual curb ramp locations, we now follow the same convention used by ADA construction compliance inspectors.  In this schema, individual pedestrian locations such as intersection corners, medians, and "pork chops" (aka “protected right turn pedestrian islands”) as well mid-block pedestrian crossings and roundabout edge crossings, are now the locational "parent" records.  For each of those locations, separate curb ramp and Accessible Pedestrian Signal (APS) button station inspections are completed (without spatial information of their own).

Currently, this layer only includes data collected starting in April 2024, but previous ramp and signal data will be added to it as it is cleaned, transormed, and consolidated.  Like other MnDOT pedestrian infrastructure data, new records are added to this feature through field collection during the warmer months of the year, with data quality assurance and cleanup happening year round.
 
Any questions about this data should be directed to interrim Pedestrian Infrastructure Data & Application Steward Galen Sjostrom at galen.sjostrom@state.mn.us.
results.snippet: The three sets of data in this layer service comprise the revised schema for pedestrian curb ramp and crossing signal button inspections.  General details for each area are recorded in the Pedestrian Location point layer, and more precise measurements and other attributes (particularly those used to assess ADA compliance) for curb ramps and signal buttons are recorded in their respective related tables.
results.accessInformation: Minnesota Department of Transportation, Asset Management Group and Statewide ADA Compliance Unit
results.licenseInfo:

results.name: Accessible_Pedestrian_Signals_(Active)
results.title: Accessible Pedestrian Signals (Active)
results.description:
This view, Accessible Pedestrian Signals (Active), is a subset derived from Traffic Signals Assemblies dataset where the following definition query is applied:
(CURRENT_STATUS = "INSVC" OR "TEMPOUTSVC" OR ' ' ) AND PP_MODELTYPE CONTAINS "NAV-".┬á

Displays a view of to show the location and display attributes of the existing Accessible Pedestrian Signals (APS) at intersections within the city limits. APS devices use non-visual formats such as tactile / vibrational and auditory signals to communicate information about walk and don’t walk intervals at signalized intersections. These features support pedestrians who are blind or have low vision. (APS).

Refresh Cycle: Daily

Feature Class: V_SIGNALS
results.snippet: Displays subset of traffic signal assemblies maintained by the Seattle Department of Transportation.
results.accessInformation: City of Seattle, Seattle Department of Transportation
results.licenseInfo: The City of Seattle makes no representation or warranty as to its accuracy, and in particular, its accuracy as to labeling, dimensions, contours, property boundaries, or placement or location of any map feature thereof.

results.name: City_of_Sacramento_Traffic_Signals
results.title: City of Sacramento Traffic Signals
results.description: City of Sacramento Traffic Signals. ┬áThe locations show street intersection points that contain one or more traffic signals at the intersection. ┬áThese data are maintained by City of Sacramento Public Work and GIS staff. ┬áThe data is considered "as-is" since the data has on-going routine updates.
